Award.AwardTitle: Travel Awards for Students from Underrepresented Groups for the 2017 Cognitive Development Society (CDS) Meeting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cognitive Development Society (CDS) seeks to promote the attendance, at its 2017 meeting, of young scholars from groups traditionally underrepresented in the Developmental Sciences. This award will support travel awards to graduate students, post-docs, and young investigators from these groups, broadly defined. Travel awards increase the likelihood that young scholars will have the means to attend and present their work at CDS, and will support them through their participation in a mentoring program, designed to ensure that young scholars will have a productive experience at the conference. A broader impact of the present award is to increase the likelihood that the conference experience endures beyond the conference itself by strengthening the professional networks of young scholars from traditionally underrepresented groups.

The present award will increase the diversity of the CDS membership through several mechanisms. Supporting travel to the CDS conference increases the number of young scholars from underrepresented groups who are able to attend the conference. To promote the awardees' networking, professional socialization, and retention in the Society, funds will be used for a mentoring program that will match each young scholar with a more experienced scholar in the field, one with similar research interests. Through an organized meeting at the start of the conference with their mentors, mentees will have the opportunity to forge new professional relationships and broaden their academic network. Mentors will support their mentees by attending the young scholars' presentations. In addition, the young scholars will meet with each other and with the recipients of the 2015 travel awards to foster a community of young scholars from underrepresented groups. Finally, CDS will highlight the recipients of the 2017 travel awards at the conference by acknowledging them during an awards ceremony. Anonymous feedback from the young scholars and their mentors following the 2017 meeting will help ensure that CDS can improve upon the effectiveness of its travel awards in achieving its goal of increasing the involvement of scholars traditionally under-represented in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cognitive Development Society (CDS) supported 27 young scholars from groups traditionally underrepresented in the Developmental Sciences to attend its 2017 meeting in Portland, OR. The award recipients, 4 post-doctoral fellows and 23 graduate students, received travel support and participated in a mentoring program. Each young scholar was paired with an established researcher with similar research interests. The mentor and mentees met at an organized meeting, immediately prior to the start of the conference. The meeting allowed one-on-one discussions of research and professional development. The conference mentors also attended the young scholar’s presentation. There were many intellectual merits to the CDS travel awards. The mentoring program provided an important opportunity for young scholars to forge new academic connections and to discuss their work and professional development with an established researcher.  An anonymous survey following the conference showed that the young scholars found the mentoring program to be the most beneficial feature of the CDS travel awards. Several young scholars noted that the travel award made it possible for them to attend the conference. Without exception, all young scholars appreciated the opportunity to discuss their work with a well-established scholar in the field that they may not otherwise have had the opportunity to meet. A broader impact of the present award was to strengthen the professional networks of young scholars from traditionally underrepresented groups.

The present award increased the diversity of the CDS membership through several mechanisms. Providing support for travel to the CDS conference increased the number of young scholars from underrepresented groups who are able to attend the conference. The mentoring program promoted the awardees' networking, professional socialization, and retention in the Society. The organized meeting at the start of the conference between mentors and mentees forged new professional relationships and broaden their academic network. Several mentees expected to maintain their connection with the conference mentor in the future. The young scholars also had the opportunity to meet with each other and with the recipients of the 2015 travel awards to promote a sense of community of young scholars from underrepresented groups.  Finally, CDS highlighted the recipients of the 2017 travel awards at the conference by acknowledging them during an awards ceremony. Feedback from the young scholars following the 2017 meeting noted that travel awards were central to increasing the value of attending the CDS conference and in creating a stronger professional connections.
